Description: Digital photograph (colour); view of engraved rock art on a sandstone rock face showing the pecked, infilled figures of a giraffe, three Barbary sheep, two dogs and five unidentified shapes. All figures are upright. The giraffe is large and central, facing right with the head cut off the edge of the image at the top and the tail raised over its back. The leftmost two of the three Barbary sheep, distinguishable by their horns, each appear to be chased or followed dogs. One pairing is to the left of the giraffe, one to the right. All of these figures face left and there is a single Barbary sheep facing left at the bottom right. To the left of this are two indistinguishable pecked shapes. The giraffe’s tail is raised over its back and at the bottom and top left are two further unidentified clusters of pecking. A 5cm photo scale has been fitted at the base of the image. Wadi Hamra, Egypt. Scanned
Curator's comments: Wadi Hamra is a canyon-like valley with a relatively flat floor between one and 200m wide, curling more or less south into the Gilf Kebir plateau in Egypt’s Western Desert. There are three known rock art sites, all for engravings and first reported by Has Rhotert in 1952: The first is an old river terrace with numerous engravings of giraffe and a few of ostrich, cattle and abstract fan-shaped grooves, with stone circles and shallow depressions on the top. The second is several engravings further southwest. The third stands opposite the branch containing the first site: a rocky outcrop about 15 m high with a number of engravings along the base.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Trust for African Rock Art
